1.title: API reference
1.content:
/>

Throughout the reference, the type `T` represents the type of the validation schema, extending `Record<string, unknown>`. For example, in a form with name and email, name being optional:



The `Nested<T, R>` type replaces all primitive values of `T` with `R`, and removes any optional modifier. In the above example:



The type `M` represents the status message type, default `any`.



A `ValidationAdapter<T, In>` and `ClientValidationAdapter<T, In>` are the adapters used to wrap the schema, based on the selected validation library. `In` is the input type of the schema, as transformations and pipes can make it differ from `T`, but usually they are the same. Example:

2.title: superValidate(adapter | data, adapter? | options?, options?)
2.content:
If you want the form to be initially empty, you can pass the adapter as the first parameter:



If you want to populate the form, for example, from a database, `URL` parameters in the load function, or `FormData` in the form actions, send the data as the first parameter and the adapter second:
2.code:
superValidate<T, M = any, In = T>(
  adapter: ValidationAdapter<T, In>,
  options?: SuperValidateOptions
): Promise<SuperValidated<T, M, In>>
superValidate<T, M = any, In = T>(
  data:
    | RequestEvent
    | Request
    | FormData
    | URL
    | URLSearchParams
    | Partial<In>
    | null
    | undefined,
  adapter: ValidationAdapter<T, In>,
  options?: SuperValidateOptions
): Promise<SuperValidated<T, M, In>>

3.title: superValidate options
3.content: See the page about multiple forms for information about when to use `id`.
3.code:
SuperValidateOptions = {
  errors?: boolean;           // Add or remove errors from output (valid status is always preserved)
  id?: string;                // Form id, for multiple forms support. Set automatically by default
  preprocessed?: (keyof T)[]; // Bypass superValidate data coercion for posted fields in this array
  defaults?: T;               // Override default values from the schema
  jsonSchema?: JSONSchema;    // Override JSON schema from the adapter
  strict?: boolean;           // If true, validate exactly the posted data, no defaults added
  allowFiles?: boolean;       // If false, set all posted File objects to undefined
}

4.title: superValidate return type
4.content:
If data is empty, a `SuperValidated` object with default values for the schema is returned:



See this page for a list of default schema values.

5.title: setError(form, field, error, options?)
5.content:
For setting errors on the form after validation. It returns a `fail(status, { form })` so it can be returned immediately, or more errors can be added by calling it multiple times before returning.

Use the `overwrite` option to remove all previously set errors for the field, and `status` to set a different status than the default `400` (which must be in the range 400-599).

To set a form-level error, the `field` argument can be skipped, or set to an empty string.To set a form-level error, the `field` argument can be skipped, or set to an empty string.To set an array-level error, append `._errors` to the field parameter, like `"tags._errors"`.To set an array-level error, append `._errors` to the field parameter, like `"tags._errors"`.

6.title: message(form, message, options?)
6.content:
`message` is a convenience method for setting `form.message`, best explained by an example:



Note that the `status` option must be in the range `400-599`.

7.title: defaultValues(schema)
7.content:
Returns the default values for a schema, either the Superforms defaults or the ones you set on the schema yourself.



This corresponds to the `form.data` returned from `const form = await superValidate(zod(schema))`.

8.title: actionResult(type, data?, options? | status?)
8.content:
When using an endpoint (a `+server.ts` file) instead of form actions, you must return an `ActionResult` to a form that has `use:enhance` applied. Anything else won't work, not even throwing a redirect, since superForm expects an ActionResult.

The `actionResult` function helps you construct one in a `Response` object, so you can return a validation object from your API/endpoints.



The default status codes for each result type are shown, so you don't need to include them if they're the same.

Additionally, the `redirect` version can send a flash message as a third parameter, in case you're using flash messages. It can also set options for the flash cookie that's being set.

9.title: Login request example

10.title: superForm options
10.content: See SubmitFunction for details about the `onSubmit` arguments, and ActionResult for `onResult`.

11.title: defaults
11.content: The `defaults` function can be useful on the client in Svelte components and SPA mode, since components cannot have top-level `await`.
11.code:
defaults<T, M = any>(
  data:
    | Partial<T>
    | null
    | undefined,
  schema: ClientValidationAdapter<T>,
  options?: SuperValidateOptions
): SuperValidated<T, M, In>

12.title: Proxy objects
12.content: A proxy handles bi-directional updates and data transformation of a corresponding form field. Updates in either the proxy or data it points to, will reflect in the other.

13.title: intProxy(form, fieldName, options?)
13.content:
Creates a string store for an integer field in the schema. It's rarely needed as Svelte handles this automatically with `bind:value`. 



Options:



Use the `empty` option to set the field to `null` or `undefined` if the value is falsy, Which includes the number zero, unless `emptyIfZero` is set to `false`. The reverse, `zeroIfEmpty`, sets the field to zero if the string value of the proxy is empty.

14.title: numberProxy(form, fieldName, options?)
14.content:
Creates a string store for a number field in the schema. It's rarely needed as Svelte handles this automatically with `bind:value`. 



Options:



Use the `empty` option to set the field to `null` or `undefined` if the value is falsy. (Which includes the number zero, unless `emptyIfZero` is set to `false`.)

15.title: booleanProxy(form, fieldName, options?)
15.content:
Creates a string store for a boolean schema field. The option can be used to change what string value should represent `true`. An empty string always represents `false`.



Options:

16.title: dateProxy(form, fieldName, options?)
16.content:
Creates a string store for a Date schema field. The option can be used to change the proxied string format of the date.



Options:

17.title: stringProxy(form, fieldName, options)
17.content:
Creates a string store for a string schema field. It may look redundant, but the option can be useful if you need to convert an empty string to `null` or `undefined`.



Options:

18.title: formFieldProxy(superForm, fieldName, options)
18.content:
Proxies a form field, returning stores similar to `superForm` but for a single field. For arrays in the schema, see below for how to create an `arrayProxy`.

The whole object returned from `superForm` is required here, not just the `$form` store.

Options:



The option can be used to prevent tainting the form when modifying the proxy.

For more details about formFieldProxy, see the components page.
18.code:
<script lang="ts">
  import { superForm, formFieldProxy } from 'sveltekit-superforms';

  export let data;

  const theForm = superForm(data.form); // The whole superForm object is required
  const { form } = theForm; // Deconstruct as usual here

  const { path, value, errors, constraints, tainted } = formFieldProxy(theForm, 'name');
</script>
{
  taint: boolean | 'untaint' | 'untaint-all' = true;
}

19.title: arrayProxy(superForm, fieldName, options)
19.content:
Proxies an array in a form, returning stores similar to `superForm` but for the array.

The whole object returned from `superForm` is required here, not just the `$form` store.

`errors` displays errors for the *array itself*, for example if the number of items are too few.`errors` displays errors for the array itself, for example if the number of items are too few.`fieldErrors` is an array that lists errors for the *contents* of the array.`fieldErrors` is an array that lists errors for the contents of the array.

Options:



The option can be used to prevent tainting the form when modifying the proxy.

An example of how to use `arrayProxy` in a component is available on Stackblitz.
19.code:
<script lang="ts">
  import { superForm, arrayProxy } from 'sveltekit-superforms';

  export let data;

  const theForm = superForm(data.form); // The whole superForm object is required
  const { form } = theForm; // Deconstruct as usual here

  const { path, values, errors, fieldErrors } = arrayProxy(theForm, 'tags');
</script>
{
  taint: boolean | 'untaint' | 'untaint-all' = true;
}

20.title: fieldProxy(object, fieldName)
20.content: Proxies field access in any object, usually in `$form`, but in that case `formFieldProxy` and `arrayProxy` are more convenient.
20.code:
<script lang="ts">
  import { superForm, fieldProxy } from 'sveltekit-superforms';
  export let data;

  const { form } = superForm(data.form);

  // Proxy any field in an object
  const nameProxy = fieldProxy(form, 'name');
</script>

46.title: Forms and fields in components
46.content:
By looking at the rather simple get started tutorial, it's obvious that quite a bit of boilerplate code adds up for a Superform:



And it also gets bad in the script part when you have more than a couple of forms on the page:



This leads to the question of whether a form and its fields can be factored out into components?
46.code: {#if $errors.name} {$errors.name} {/if}

47.title: Factoring out a form
47.content:
To do this, you need the type of the schema, which can be defined as follows:

src/lib/schemas.ts



Now you can import and use this type in a separate component:

src/routes/LoginForm.svelte



Use it by passing the form data from `+page.svelte` to the component, making it much less cluttered:

+page.svelte

48.title: Factoring out form fields
48.content:
Since `bind` is available on Svelte components, we can make a `TextInput` component quite easily:

TextInput.svelte



The `type` attribute on input elements must be hard-coded in Svelte, explained here. Especially important for `type="number"`.+page.svelte



(Note that you must bind directly to `$form.tags` with the index, you cannot use the each loop variable, hence the underscore.)

This is a bit better and will certainly help when the components require some styling, but there are still plenty of attributes. Can we do even better?
48.code:
{#if errors}{errors}{/if}

Tags

{#each $form.tags as _, i} {/each}

49.title: Using a fieldProxy
49.content:
You may have used proxy objects for converting an input field string like `"2023-04-12"` into a `Date`, but that's a special usage of proxies. They can actually be used for any part of the form data, to have a store that can modify a part of the `$form` store. If you want to update just `$form.name`, for example:



Any updates to `$name` will reflect in `$form.name`. Note that this will also taint that field, so if this is not intended, you can use the whole superForm object and add an option:



A `fieldProxy` isn't enough here, however. We'd still have to make proxies for `form`, `errors`, and `constraints`, and then we're back to the same problem again.
49.code:
Name: {$name}
const theForm = superForm(data.form); const { form } = theForm; const name = fieldProxy(theForm, 'name', { taint: false });

50.title: Using a formFieldProxy
50.content:
The solution is to use a `formFieldProxy`, which is a helper function for producing the above proxies from a form. To do this, we cannot immediately deconstruct what we need from `superForm` since `formFieldProxy` takes the form itself as an argument:



But we didn't want to pass all those proxies, so let's imagine a component that will handle even the above proxy creation for us.



How nice would this be? This can actually be pulled off in a typesafe way with a bit of Svelte magic:



The Svelte syntax requires `Record<string, unknown>` to be defined before its used in the `generics` attribute, so we have to import it in a module context. Now when `T` is defined (the schema object type), we can use it in the `form` prop to ensure that only a `SuperForm` matching the `field` prop is used.

The `FormPathLeaves` type prevents using a field that isn't at the end of the schema (the "leaves" of the schema tree). This means that arrays and objects cannot be used in `formFieldProxy`. Array-level errors are handled like this.
50.code: {#if $errors}{$errors}{/if}

51.title: A minor issue: Checkboxes
51.content:
A workaround is required for checkboxes, since they don't bind with `bind:value`, rather with `bind:checked`, which requires a `boolean`.

Because our component is generic, `value` returned from `formFieldProxy` can't be `boolean` specifically, so we need to make a specific checkbox component to use it, or cast it with a dynamic declaration:



Checkboxes, especially grouped ones, can be tricky to handle. Read the Svelte tutorial about bind:group, and see the Ice cream example on Stackblitz if you're having trouble with it.
51.code:
<script lang="ts">
  import type { Writable } from 'svelte/store';
  // ... other imports and props

  const { value, errors, constraints } = formFieldProxy(form, field);

  $: boolValue = value as Writable<boolean>;
</script>

<input
  name={field}
  type="checkbox"
  class="checkbox"
  bind:checked={$boolValue}
  {...$constraints}
  {...$$restProps} 
/>

52.title: Using the componentized field in awesome ways
52.content:
Using this component is now as simple as:



But to show off some super proxy power, let's recreate the tags example above with the `TextField` component:



We can now produce a type-safe text field for any object inside our data, which will update the `$form` store.

In general, nested data requires the `dataType` option to be set to `'json'`, but this example works without it, even without `use:enhance`, since arrays of primitive values are coerced automatically.

I hope you now feel under your fingers the superpowers that Superforms bring! 💥
52.code:
Tags

{#each $form.tags as _, i} {/each}

64.title: Proxy objects
64.content: A proxy handles bi-directional updates and data transformation of a corresponding form field. Updates in either the proxy or data it points to, will reflect in the other.

65.title: intProxy(form, fieldName, options?)
65.content:
Creates a string store for an integer field in the schema. It's rarely needed as Svelte handles this automatically with `bind:value`. 



Options:



Use the `empty` option to set the field to `null` or `undefined` if the value is falsy, Which includes the number zero, unless `emptyIfZero` is set to `false`. The reverse, `zeroIfEmpty`, sets the field to zero if the string value of the proxy is empty.

66.title: numberProxy(form, fieldName, options?)
66.content:
Creates a string store for a number field in the schema. It's rarely needed as Svelte handles this automatically with `bind:value`. 



Options:



Use the `empty` option to set the field to `null` or `undefined` if the value is falsy. (Which includes the number zero, unless `emptyIfZero` is set to `false`.)

67.title: booleanProxy(form, fieldName, options?)
67.content:
Creates a string store for a boolean schema field. The option can be used to change what string value should represent `true`. An empty string always represents `false`.



Options:

68.title: dateProxy(form, fieldName, options?)
68.content:
Creates a string store for a Date schema field. The option can be used to change the proxied string format of the date.



Options:

69.title: stringProxy(form, fieldName, options)
69.content:
Creates a string store for a string schema field. It may look redundant, but the option can be useful if you need to convert an empty string to `null` or `undefined`.



Options:

70.title: formFieldProxy(superForm, fieldName, options)
70.content:
Proxies a form field, returning stores similar to `superForm` but for a single field. For arrays in the schema, see below for how to create an `arrayProxy`.

The whole object returned from `superForm` is required here, not just the `$form` store.

Options:



The option can be used to prevent tainting the form when modifying the proxy.

For more details about formFieldProxy, see the components page.
70.code:
<script lang="ts">
  import { superForm, formFieldProxy } from 'sveltekit-superforms';

  export let data;

  const theForm = superForm(data.form); // The whole superForm object is required
  const { form } = theForm; // Deconstruct as usual here

  const { path, value, errors, constraints, tainted } = formFieldProxy(theForm, 'name');
</script>
{
  taint: boolean | 'untaint' | 'untaint-all' = true;
}

71.title: arrayProxy(superForm, fieldName, options)
71.content:
Proxies an array in a form, returning stores similar to `superForm` but for the array.

The whole object returned from `superForm` is required here, not just the `$form` store.

`errors` displays errors for the *array itself*, for example if the number of items are too few.`errors` displays errors for the array itself, for example if the number of items are too few.`fieldErrors` is an array that lists errors for the *contents* of the array.`fieldErrors` is an array that lists errors for the contents of the array.

Options:



The option can be used to prevent tainting the form when modifying the proxy.

An example of how to use `arrayProxy` in a component is available on Stackblitz.
71.code:
<script lang="ts">
  import { superForm, arrayProxy } from 'sveltekit-superforms';

  export let data;

  const theForm = superForm(data.form); // The whole superForm object is required
  const { form } = theForm; // Deconstruct as usual here

  const { path, values, errors, fieldErrors } = arrayProxy(theForm, 'tags');
</script>
{
  taint: boolean | 'untaint' | 'untaint-all' = true;
}

72.title: fieldProxy(object, fieldName)
72.content: Proxies field access in any object, usually in `$form`, but in that case `formFieldProxy` and `arrayProxy` are more convenient.
72.code:
<script lang="ts">
  import { superForm, fieldProxy } from 'sveltekit-superforms';
  export let data;

  const { form } = superForm(data.form);

  // Proxy any field in an object
  const nameProxy = fieldProxy(form, 'name');
</script>

73.title: Proxy example
73.content:
Given the following schema:



A proxy for a HTML date field can be used like this:

74.title: SuperDebug
74.content:
`SuperDebug` is a must-have debugging component that gives you colorized and nicely formatted output for any data structure, usually `$form`. 

More information and usage examples can be found on the SuperDebug page.

76.title: Forms and fields in components
76.content:
By looking at the rather simple get started tutorial, it's obvious that quite a bit of boilerplate code adds up for a Superform:



And it also gets bad in the script part when you have more than a couple of forms on the page:



This leads to the question of whether a form and its fields can be factored out into components?
76.code: {#if $errors.name} {$errors.name} {/if}

77.title: Factoring out a form
77.content:
To do this, you need the type of the schema, which can be defined as follows:

src/lib/schemas.ts



Now you can import and use this type in a separate component:

src/routes/LoginForm.svelte



Use it by passing the form data from `+page.svelte` to the component, making it much less cluttered:

+page.svelte

78.title: Factoring out form fields
78.content:
Since `bind` is available on Svelte components, we can make a `TextInput` component quite easily:

TextInput.svelte



The `type` attribute on input elements must be hard-coded in Svelte, explained here. Especially important for `type="number"`.+page.svelte



(Note that you must bind directly to `$form.tags` with the index, you cannot use the each loop variable, hence the underscore.)

This is a bit better and will certainly help when the components require some styling, but there are still plenty of attributes. Can we do even better?
78.code:
{#if errors}{errors}{/if}

Tags

{#each $form.tags as _, i} {/each}

79.title: Using a fieldProxy
79.content:
You may have used proxy objects for converting an input field string like `"2023-04-12"` into a `Date`, but that's a special usage of proxies. They can actually be used for any part of the form data, to have a store that can modify a part of the `$form` store. If you want to update just `$form.name`, for example:



Any updates to `$name` will reflect in `$form.name`. Note that this will also taint that field, so if this is not intended, you can use the whole superForm object and add an option:



A `fieldProxy` isn't enough here, however. We'd still have to make proxies for `form`, `errors`, and `constraints`, and then we're back to the same problem again.
79.code:
Name: {$name}
const theForm = superForm(data.form); const { form } = theForm; const name = fieldProxy(theForm, 'name', { taint: false });

80.title: Using a formFieldProxy
80.content:
The solution is to use a `formFieldProxy`, which is a helper function for producing the above proxies from a form. To do this, we cannot immediately deconstruct what we need from `superForm` since `formFieldProxy` takes the form itself as an argument:



But we didn't want to pass all those proxies, so let's imagine a component that will handle even the above proxy creation for us.



How nice would this be? This can actually be pulled off in a typesafe way with a bit of Svelte magic:



The Svelte syntax requires `Record<string, unknown>` to be defined before its used in the `generics` attribute, so we have to import it in a module context. Now when `T` is defined (the schema object type), we can use it in the `form` prop to ensure that only a `SuperForm` matching the `field` prop is used.

The `FormPathLeaves` type prevents using a field that isn't at the end of the schema (the "leaves" of the schema tree). This means that arrays and objects cannot be used in `formFieldProxy`. Array-level errors are handled like this.
80.code: {#if $errors}{$errors}{/if}

81.title: A minor issue: Checkboxes
81.content:
A workaround is required for checkboxes, since they don't bind with `bind:value`, rather with `bind:checked`, which requires a `boolean`.

Because our component is generic, `value` returned from `formFieldProxy` can't be `boolean` specifically, so we need to make a specific checkbox component to use it, or cast it with a dynamic declaration:



Checkboxes, especially grouped ones, can be tricky to handle. Read the Svelte tutorial about bind:group, and see the Ice cream example on Stackblitz if you're having trouble with it.
81.code:
<script lang="ts">
  import type { Writable } from 'svelte/store';
  // ... other imports and props

  const { value, errors, constraints } = formFieldProxy(form, field);

  $: boolValue = value as Writable<boolean>;
</script>

<input
  name={field}
  type="checkbox"
  class="checkbox"
  bind:checked={$boolValue}
  {...$constraints}
  {...$$restProps} 
/>

82.title: Using the componentized field in awesome ways
82.content:
Using this component is now as simple as:



But to show off some super proxy power, let's recreate the tags example above with the `TextField` component:



We can now produce a type-safe text field for any object inside our data, which will update the `$form` store.

In general, nested data requires the `dataType` option to be set to `'json'`, but this example works without it, even without `use:enhance`, since arrays of primitive values are coerced automatically.

I hope you now feel under your fingers the superpowers that Superforms bring! 💥
82.code:
Tags

{#each $form.tags as _, i} {/each}

84.title: Contributing
84.content:
Contributions to Superforms are very welcome! The issues and discussion pages on Github are always open for comments, and if you want to contribute some code, it's quite easy. Just fork either the Superforms repository or its website, and then you just need to execute the following to be up and running:





If you find a typo on the website, you can make a quick PR directly in its Github repository.
84.code:
npm install
npm run dev
pnpm install
pnpm dev

92.title: Designing a CRUD interface
92.content:
/>

An excellent use case for Superforms is a backend interface, commonly used as in the acronym CRUD (Create, Read, Update, Delete):

Display an empty formDisplay an empty formPOST the form, validate the dataPOST the form, validate the dataCreate a new entity with the data **(Create)**Create a new entity with the data (Create)Fetch the entity **(Read)**Fetch the entity (Read)Display it in a formDisplay it in a formPOST the form, validate the dataPOST the form, validate the dataUpdate the entity with the data **(Update)**Update the entity with the data (Update)Delete the entity **(Delete)**Delete the entity (Delete)??????Profit!Profit!

Because you can send the data model to the `superValidate` function and have the form directly populated, it becomes quite easy to implement the above steps.

93.content: To follow along, there are three ways:

94.content: Instead of the text version below, here's the video version (using version 1 of Superforms, but the differences are small).

95.content: The code is available on Stackblitz; just click the link, and you're up and running in the browser in 15 seconds!

96.title: New SvelteKit project
96.content:
Start from scratch in a new SvelteKit project by executing one of the following commands in your project directory:





Select Skeleton project and Typescript syntax at the prompts, the rest is up to you. Then add this to `<head>` in src/app.html for a much nicer visual experience:
96.code:
npm create svelte@latest
pnpm create svelte@latest
<link
  rel="stylesheet"
  href="https://unpkg.com/normalize.css@8.0.1/normalize.css" />
<link rel="stylesheet" href="https://unpkg.com/sakura.css/css/sakura.css" />

97.title: Start - Creating a test database
97.content:
When you have the code up and running, we need a user schema, and a mock database for testing. We will use Zod as a validation library, but its schema can easily be converted to others.

src/lib/users.ts



This mock database in the shape of an array will be helpful for testing our CRUD operations.

98.title: Form vs. database schemas
98.content:
When starting on the server page, we'll encounter a thing about validation schemas. Our `userSchema` is for database integrity, so an `id` must exist there. But we want to create an entity, and must therefore allow `id` not to exist when creating users.

Fortunately, Zod makes it quite easy to append a modifier to a field without duplicating the whole schema by extending it:

src/routes/users/[[id]]/+page.server.ts



(Of course, the original `userSchema` is kept intact.)

With this, Create and Update can now use the same schema, which means that they can share the same user interface. This is a fundamental idea in Superforms: you can pass either empty data or an entity partially matching the schema to `superValidate`, and it will generate default values for any non-specified fields, ensuring type safety.

99.title: Reading a user from the database
99.content:
Let's add a load function to the page, using the SvelteKit route parameters to look up the requested user:

src/routes/users/[[id]]/+page.server.ts



Some simple logic is used to find the user, and then detect if a 404 should be displayed. At the end, we're returning `form` as usual, but also `users`, so they can be displayed as a list.

(Sometimes, CRUDL is used as an acronym, since listing is also fundamental to data management.)

Now that we have loaded the data, let's display it in a page component:

src/routes/users/[[id]]/+page.svelte



There are plenty of variables extracted from `superForm`; refer to the API reference for a complete list. We've also setting the `resetForm` to `false`, since the data should be kept after editing.

We've also prepared a status message, using `$page.status` to test for success or failure, and we're using `$form.id` to display a "Create user" or "Update user" title. Now let's add the form itself:

src/routes/users/[[id]]/+page.svelte (continued)



Remember to use SuperDebug if you want to see your form data live!

100.title: Creating and Updating a user
100.content:
With this, the form should be ready for creating a user. Let's add the form action for that:

src/routes/users/[[id]]/+page.server.ts



This is where you should access your database API. In our case, we're only doing some array manipulations.

With this, we have 3 out of 4 letters of CRUD in about 150 lines of code, half of it HTML!

101.title: Deleting a user
101.content:
To delete a user, we can make use of the HTML `button` element, which can have a name and a value that will be passed only if that specific button was used to post the form. Add this at the end of the form:

src/routes/users/[[id]]/+page.svelte



In the form action, we now use the `FormData` from the request to check if the delete button was pressed.

We can also add a delayed button in the form to mimick the behavior of a slow network call:



We shouldn't use the schema since `delete` and `delayed` are not a part of the user, but it's not a big change:

src/routes/users/[[id]]/+page.server.ts



Now all four CRUD operations are complete! An issue, however, is that we have to redirect after deleting to avoid a 404, so we cannot use `form.message` to show "User deleted", since the validation data won't exist after redirecting.

Redirecting with a message is a general problem; for example, maybe we'd like to redirect to the newly created user after it's been created. Fortunately, there is a solution; the sister library to Superforms handles this. Read more about it here.

102.title: Listing the users
102.content:
The last loose thread is to display a list of the users. It'll be quite trivial; add this to the top of `+page.svelte`:

src/routes/+page.svelte



And some styling for everything at the end:



That's it! Thank you for following along, the code is available here on Stackblitz.

If you have any questions, see the help & support page.
102.code:
Users

{#each data.users as user} {user.name} {/each}

103.content:
/>

An excellent use case for Superforms is a backend interface, commonly used as in the acronym CRUD (Create, Read, Update, Delete):

Display an empty formDisplay an empty formPOST the form, validate the dataPOST the form, validate the dataCreate a new entity with the data **(Create)**Create a new entity with the data (Create)Fetch the entity **(Read)**Fetch the entity (Read)Display it in a formDisplay it in a formPOST the form, validate the dataPOST the form, validate the dataUpdate the entity with the data **(Update)**Update the entity with the data (Update)Delete the entity **(Delete)**Delete the entity (Delete)??????Profit!Profit!

Because you can send the data model to the `superValidate` function and have the form directly populated, it becomes quite easy to implement the above steps.

Redirecting with a message is a general problem; for example, maybe we'd like to redirect to the newly created user after it's been created. Fortunately, there is a solution; the sister library to Superforms handles this. Read more about it here.

124.title: Listing the users
124.content:
The last loose thread is to display a list of the users. It'll be quite trivial; add this to the top of `+page.svelte`:

src/routes/+page.svelte



And some styling for everything at the end:



That's it! Thank you for following along, the code is available here on Stackblitz.

If you have any questions, see the help & support page.
124.code:
Users

{#each data.users as user} {user.name} {/each}

125.title: Default values
125.content:
/>

When `superValidate` encounters a schema field that isn't optional, and when its supplied data is empty, a default value is returned to the form, to ensure that the type is correct:

typevaluestring`""`number`0`boolean`false`Array`[]`object`{}`bigint`BigInt(0)`symbol`Symbol()`

126.title: Changing a default value
126.content:
You can, of course, set your own default values in the schema, using the `default` method in Zod, for example. You can even abuse the typing system a bit to handle the classic "agree to terms" checkbox:



This looks a bit strange, but will ensure that the age isn't set to 0 as default (which will hide placeholder text in the input field), and also ensure that the agree checkbox is unchecked as default while also only accepting `true` (checked) as a value.

Since the default value will not correspond to the type, this will not work when using Zod's refine on the whole schema. Validation itself is no problem though, `form.valid` will be `false` if these values are posted, which should be the main determinant of whether the data is trustworthy.

127.title: optional vs. nullable
127.content: Fields set to `null` will take precedence over `undefined`, so a field that is both `nullable` and `optional` will have `null` as its default value. Otherwise, it's `undefined`.

128.title: Explicit defaults
128.content:
Enums and unions must have an explicit default value:



If the field is nullable or optional, there's no need for a default value (but it can still be set).

130.title: Forms and fields in components
130.content:
By looking at the rather simple get started tutorial, it's obvious that quite a bit of boilerplate code adds up for a Superform:



And it also gets bad in the script part when you have more than a couple of forms on the page:



This leads to the question of whether a form and its fields can be factored out into components?
130.code: {#if $errors.name} {$errors.name} {/if}

131.title: Factoring out a form
131.content:
To do this, you need the type of the schema, which can be defined as follows:

src/lib/schemas.ts



Now you can import and use this type in a separate component:

src/routes/LoginForm.svelte



Use it by passing the form data from `+page.svelte` to the component, making it much less cluttered:

+page.svelte

132.title: Factoring out form fields
132.content:
Since `bind` is available on Svelte components, we can make a `TextInput` component quite easily:

TextInput.svelte



The `type` attribute on input elements must be hard-coded in Svelte, explained here. Especially important for `type="number"`.+page.svelte



(Note that you must bind directly to `$form.tags` with the index, you cannot use the each loop variable, hence the underscore.)

This is a bit better and will certainly help when the components require some styling, but there are still plenty of attributes. Can we do even better?
132.code:
{#if errors}{errors}{/if}

Tags

{#each $form.tags as _, i} {/each}

133.title: Using a fieldProxy
133.content:
You may have used proxy objects for converting an input field string like `"2023-04-12"` into a `Date`, but that's a special usage of proxies. They can actually be used for any part of the form data, to have a store that can modify a part of the `$form` store. If you want to update just `$form.name`, for example:



Any updates to `$name` will reflect in `$form.name`. Note that this will also taint that field, so if this is not intended, you can use the whole superForm object and add an option:



A `fieldProxy` isn't enough here, however. We'd still have to make proxies for `form`, `errors`, and `constraints`, and then we're back to the same problem again.
133.code:
Name: {$name}
const theForm = superForm(data.form); const { form } = theForm; const name = fieldProxy(theForm, 'name', { taint: false });

134.title: Using a formFieldProxy
134.content:
The solution is to use a `formFieldProxy`, which is a helper function for producing the above proxies from a form. To do this, we cannot immediately deconstruct what we need from `superForm` since `formFieldProxy` takes the form itself as an argument:



But we didn't want to pass all those proxies, so let's imagine a component that will handle even the above proxy creation for us.



How nice would this be? This can actually be pulled off in a typesafe way with a bit of Svelte magic:



The Svelte syntax requires `Record<string, unknown>` to be defined before its used in the `generics` attribute, so we have to import it in a module context. Now when `T` is defined (the schema object type), we can use it in the `form` prop to ensure that only a `SuperForm` matching the `field` prop is used.

The `FormPathLeaves` type prevents using a field that isn't at the end of the schema (the "leaves" of the schema tree). This means that arrays and objects cannot be used in `formFieldProxy`. Array-level errors are handled like this.
134.code: {#if $errors}{$errors}{/if}

135.title: A minor issue: Checkboxes
135.content:
A workaround is required for checkboxes, since they don't bind with `bind:value`, rather with `bind:checked`, which requires a `boolean`.

Because our component is generic, `value` returned from `formFieldProxy` can't be `boolean` specifically, so we need to make a specific checkbox component to use it, or cast it with a dynamic declaration:



Checkboxes, especially grouped ones, can be tricky to handle. Read the Svelte tutorial about bind:group, and see the Ice cream example on Stackblitz if you're having trouble with it.
135.code:
<script lang="ts">
  import type { Writable } from 'svelte/store';
  // ... other imports and props

  const { value, errors, constraints } = formFieldProxy(form, field);

  $: boolValue = value as Writable<boolean>;
</script>

<input
  name={field}
  type="checkbox"
  class="checkbox"
  bind:checked={$boolValue}
  {...$constraints}
  {...$$restProps} 
/>

136.title: Using the componentized field in awesome ways
136.content:
Using this component is now as simple as:



But to show off some super proxy power, let's recreate the tags example above with the `TextField` component:



We can now produce a type-safe text field for any object inside our data, which will update the `$form` store.

In general, nested data requires the `dataType` option to be set to `'json'`, but this example works without it, even without `use:enhance`, since arrays of primitive values are coerced automatically.

I hope you now feel under your fingers the superpowers that Superforms bring! 💥

{#each $form.tags as _, i} {/each}

142.title: I see the data in $form, but it's not posted to the server?
142.content: The most common mistake is to forget the `name` attribute on the input field. If you're not using `dataType: 'json'` (see nested data), the form is treated as a normal HTML form, which requires a name attribute for posting the form data.

143.title: How can I return additional data together with the form?
143.content: You're not limited to just `return { form }` in load functions and form actions; you can return anything else together with the form variables (which can also be called anything you'd like).

144.title: From a load function
144.content: It can then be accessed in `PageData` in `+page.svelte`:

145.title: From a form action
145.content:
Returning extra data from a form action is most convenient with a status message. But you can also return it directly, in which case it can be accessed in `ActionData`:





Using a status message instead avoids having to import `ActionData` and rename the `form` store.

146.title: What about the other way around, posting additional data to the server?
146.content:
You can add additional input fields to the form that aren't part of the schema, including files (see the next question), to send extra data to the server. They can then be accessed with `request.formData()` in the form action:



You can also add form data programmatically in the onSubmit event:



The onSubmit event is also a good place to modify `$form`, in case you're using nested data with `dataType: 'json'`.

147.title: How to handle file uploads?
147.content: From version 2, file uploads are handled by Superforms. Read all about it on the file uploads page.

148.title: Can I use endpoints instead of form actions?
148.content: Yes, there is a helper function for constructing an `ActionResult` that can be returned from SvelteKit endpoints. See the API reference for more information.

149.title: Can I post to an external API?
149.content: If the API doesn't return an ActionResult with the form data, you cannot post to it directly. Instead you can use the SPA mode of Superforms and call the API with fetch or similar in the `onUpdate` event.

150.title: How to submit the form programmatically?
150.content: Use the requestSubmit method on the form element to submit it manually.

151.title: Can a form be factored out into a separate component?
151.content: Yes - the answer has its own article page here.

152.title: I'm getting JSON.parse errors as response when submitting a form, why?
152.content:
This is related to the previous question. You must always return an `ActionResult` as a response to a form submission, either through a form action, where it's done automatically, or by constructing one with the actionResult helper. 

If for some reason a html page or plain text is returned, for example when a proxy server fails to handle the request and returns its own error page, the parsing of the result will fail with the slightly cryptic JSON error message.

153.title: Why am I'm getting TypeError: The body has already been consumed?
153.content:
This happens if you access the form data of the request several times, which could happen when calling `superValidate` multiple times during the same request.

To fix that problem, extract the formData before calling superValidate, and use that as an argument instead of `request` or `event`:

154.title: Why does the form get tainted without any changes, when I use a select element?
154.content:
If the schema field for the select menu doesn't have an empty string as default value, for example when it's optional, and you have an empty first option, like a "Please choose item" text, the field will be set to the empty string, tainting the form.

It can be fixed by setting the option and the default schema value to an empty string, even if it's not its proper type. See this section for an example.

155.title: How to customize error messages directly in the validation schema?
155.content: You can add them as parameters to most schema methods. Here's an example.

156.title: Can you use Superforms without any data, for example with a delete button on each row in a table?
156.content: That's possible with an empty schema, or using the `$formId` store with the button to set the form id dynamically. See this Stackblitz repo for an example.

157.title: I want to reuse common options, how to do that easily?
157.content: When you start to configure the library to suit your stack, you can create an object with default options that you will refer to instead of `superForm`:

179.title: Flash messages
179.content:
/>

Status messages are useful, but redirects will cause them to be lost, because they need to be returned in `{ form }`, usually as a response from a POST request.

Since it's common to redirect after a successful post, especially in backend interfaces, the `form.message` property isn't a general solution for displaying status messages.

The sister library to Superforms is called sveltekit-flash-message, a useful addon that handles temporary messages sent with redirects. Note that at least version 1.0 is required!

180.title: Usage
180.content:
The library works together with Superforms without any extra configuration, usually you can replace the Superforms status messages with the flash message, and that will work very well.

But if you have some special use case where you need to integrate the flash message more closely with a form, you can do that by importing its module when calling `superForm`:



Then the following options are available:

181.title: syncFlashMessage
181.content:
If set to `true`, when `form.message` is updated, the flash message will be synchronized with it, including honoring the clearOnSubmit option. 

It's important that the flash and form message types are matching, in this case. See this section on how to make the form message strongly typed.

182.title: flashMessage.onError
182.content: If a form error occurs, which happens when `error(...)` is called in a form action (and `use:enhance` is added to the form), the `flashMessage.onError` callback can be used to transform it into your flash message type, so you can display the error at the flash message instead of in `form.message`.

212.title: Migration guide
212.content:
/>

Lists the breaking changes that you need to address to upgrade from v0.x to v1.0.

213.title: Updating
213.content:
To update, change your `package.json` entry for `sveltekit-superforms` to `^1.0.0`:



(If you're using Svelte 4, you'll need at least version `^1.1.2` of Superforms.)

The guide is written with the affected methods in the headlines, so you can scan through this page and apply the changes if you're using them in your code.

214.title: superForm
214.content:
For type safety reasons, you cannot pass `null`, `undefined`, or arbitrary data to `superForm` anymore. Instead, you should be using `superValidate` to get the initial form object, by returning `{ form }` from a load function and passing it to `superForm`.

Not doing this will result in the following warning:



When this happens, you need to check the call to `superForm` and apply the above fix.

In client-only scenarios, especially in SPA's, you must use `superValidate` or `superValidateSync` before calling `superForm`. Read more on the SPA page about this.
214.code:
No form data sent to superForm, schema type safety cannot be guaranteed. Also, no constraints will exist for the form.
Set the warnings.noValidationAndConstraints option to false to disable this warning.

215.title: valid, empty, firstError
215.content:
The `$valid`, `$empty`, and `$firstError` stores are removed from the client; they weren't that useful. `$allErrors` can be used instead, together with the new `$posted` store (which shows if the form has been previously posted or not).

`empty` is removed from the object returned from `superValidate`, which type was previously called `Validation` but is now called `SuperValidated`.

216.title: setError
216.content:
The `setError` function works as before, except that you must use an empty string instead of `null` for form-level errors.

Note, however, that `setError` conflicts with client-side validation, the errors will be removed when a Zod schema is used for validation. Therefore, rely on the schema for most validation, if you're using it client-side.



The above error set in `refine` will be available on the client as `$errors._errors` as before, and will be automatically removed (or added) during client-side validation.

If you'd like a form-level message to persist, using `message` instead of `setError` will persist it until the next form submission:



Finally, the status option for `setError` (and `message`) must be in the `400-599` range.

217.title: setError (again), validate, proxy functions
217.content:
`FieldPath` is gone - the above methods are now using a string accessor like `tags[2].id` instead of the previous array syntax `['tags', 2, 'id']`.



This also applies to generic components. The types have been simplified, so you should change them to this, also described on the componentization page:



The `FormPathLeaves` type is there to prevent using a schema field that isn't at the end of the schema (the "leaves" of the schema tree)Also note that arrays and objects cannot be used in `formFieldProxy`. So if your schema is defined as:



This only applies to `formFieldProxy`, since it maps to errors and constraints as well as the form. If you want to proxy just a form value, `fieldProxy` will work with any part of the schema.

218.title: allErrors
218.content:
The signature for `allErrors` has changed, to make it easier to group related messages:



The path follows the same format as the above-described string accessor path. If you want to display all messages grouped:



Or as before, separate for each error:

219.title: defaultData
219.content:
The undocumented `defaultData` function is now called `defaultValues`. You can use this to get the default values for a schema.



See the API for documentation.
219.code:
- import { defaultData } from 'sveltekit-superforms/server`
+ import { defaultValues } from 'sveltekit-superforms/server`

220.title: message, setMessage
220.content: The `valid` option is removed from `message/setMessage`; any status >= 400 will return a fail. As with `setError`, the status code must be in the `400-599` range.

221.title: meta
221.content: The virtually unused `meta` store, which containted some basic metadata about the schema, has been removed. Use the Zod schema directly instead for reflection.

223.title: resetForm
223.content:
Resetting the form now works without `use:enhance` and without JavaScript! Just set the `resetForm` option to `true`.

If you have used the function version of `resetForm`, `() => boolean`, it is now synchronous.

224.title: errorSelector
224.content: The default `errorSelector` is now `[aria-invalid="true"],[data-invalid]`, so if you want to be more accessibility-friendly:

226.title: noErrors
226.content:
`noErrors` is removed from the options. Use `errors` instead to determine if errors should be added or not to the validation.



The 1.0 release notes have a full list of changes, and as usual, let me know on Github or Discord if something is unclear or not working.
226.code:
// Add errors to an empty form
const form = await superValidate(zod(schema), { errors: true });

227.title: Migration guide
227.content:
/>

Lists the breaking changes that you need to address to upgrade from v0.x to v1.0.

228.title: Updating
228.content:
To update, change your `package.json` entry for `sveltekit-superforms` to `^1.0.0`:



(If you're using Svelte 4, you'll need at least version `^1.1.2` of Superforms.)

The guide is written with the affected methods in the headlines, so you can scan through this page and apply the changes if you're using them in your code.

229.title: superForm
229.content:
For type safety reasons, you cannot pass `null`, `undefined`, or arbitrary data to `superForm` anymore. Instead, you should be using `superValidate` to get the initial form object, by returning `{ form }` from a load function and passing it to `superForm`.

Not doing this will result in the following warning:



When this happens, you need to check the call to `superForm` and apply the above fix.

In client-only scenarios, especially in SPA's, you must use `superValidate` or `superValidateSync` before calling `superForm`. Read more on the SPA page about this.

No form data sent to superForm, schema type safety cannot be guaranteed. Also, no constraints will exist for the form.
Set the warnings.noValidationAndConstraints option to false to disable this warning.

257.title: Superforms v2 - Migration guide
257.content:
/>

Version 2 is a big upgrade, because it now has the potential to support virtually every validation library out there. Of course, Zod is still perfectly usable with just a small modification to the code.

258.title: Changes
258.content: Here's a brief list of the changes, keep reading further down for details.

259.title: The biggest change (IMPORTANT)
259.content:
The biggest breaking change is that two options now follow the SvelteKit defaults more closely:

resetForm is now `true` as defaultresetForm is now `true` as defaulttaintedMessage is now `false` as defaulttaintedMessage is now `false` as default

But don't worry, there's no need to change these options on every form to migrate. Instead, add the following define in `vite.config.ts` to keep the original behavior:



You can do the same on a form-by-form basis by setting the `legacy` option on `superForm` to `true` as well.

260.title: superValidate
260.content:
Instead of a Zod schema, you now use an adapter for your favorite validation library. The following are currently supported:

LibraryAdapterRequires defaultsArktype`import { arktype } from 'sveltekit-superforms/adapters'`YesJoi`import { joi } from 'sveltekit-superforms/adapters'`NoTypeBox`import { typebox } from 'sveltekit-superforms/adapters'`NoValibot`import { valibot } from 'sveltekit-superforms/adapters'`NoYup`import { yup } from 'sveltekit-superforms/adapters'`NoZod`import { zod } from 'sveltekit-superforms/adapters'`NoWith the library installed and the adapter imported, all you need to do is wrap the schema with it:



The libraries in the list that requires defaults don't have full introspection capabilities (yet), in which case you need to supply the default values for the form data as an option:

261.title: Schema caching
261.content: In the example above, both the schema and the defaults are defined outside the load function, on the top level of the module. This is very important to make caching work. The adapter is memoized (cached) with its arguments, so they must be kept in memory. Therefore, define the schema, options and eventual default values for the adapter on the top level of a module, so they always refer to the same object.

262.title: Optimized client-side validation
262.content:
The client-side validation is using the smallest possible part of the adapter, to minimize the bundle size for the client. To use it, append `Client` to the adapter import, for example:



This works with the same schema as the one used on the server. If you need to switch schemas on the client (with `options.validators`), you need the full adapter.The built-in Superforms validator is now deprecated, since it requires you to do much of the type checking yourself. To keep using it, import `superformClient` and use the new `Infer` type to type it correctly with the schema, as in the following example. The input parameter can now be `undefined` as well, be sure to check for that case.



As said, this adapter requires you to do much of the error-prone type checking manually, so in general it is not a replacement for the other validation libraries. Use it only for a very good reason!

263.title: SuperValidated type parameters have changed
263.content:
If you have used type parameters for a call to `superValidate` before, or have been using the `SuperValidated` type, you now need to wrap the schema parameter with `Infer`:





If your schema uses transformations or pipes, so the input and output types are different, there's an `InferIn` type and a third type parameter that can be used.



Also, `constraints` are now optional in the `SuperValidated` type, since they won't be returned when posting data anymore, only when loading data, to save some bandwidth. This is only relevant if you're changing the constraints before calling `superForm`.

264.title: superValidateSync is renamed to defaults
264.content:
The quite popular `superValidateSync` function has changed, since it's not possible to make a synchronous validation anymore (not all validation libaries are synchronous). So if you've validated data with `superValidateSync` (in its first parameter), be aware that superValidateSync cannot do validation anymore. You need to use a `+page.ts` to do proper validation, as described on the SPA page.

Since this is a bit of a security issue, `superValidateSync` has been renamed to `defaults`.

Fortunately though, a quick Github search reveals that most of its usages are with the schema only, which requires no validation and no `+page.ts`. In that case, just call `defaults` with your adapter and eventual initial data, and you're good to go:





Note that `superValidate` can be used anywhere but on the top-level of Svelte components, so it's not completely removed from the client and SPA usage. But client-side validation is more of a convenience than ensuring data integrity. Always let an external API or a server request do a proper validation of the data before it's stored or used somewhere.

265.title: validate method with no arguments is renamed to validateForm
265.content: Previously, you could do `const result = await validate()` to get a validation result for the whole form. This overload caused a lot of typing issues, so it has now been split into `validate` for fields, and `validateForm` for the whole form. Just replace the calls to `validate()` with `validateForm()` to fix this.

266.title: id option must be a string
266.content: It's not possible to set the `id` option to `undefined` anymore, which is very rare anyway. By default, the id is automatically set to a string hash of the schema. It's only for multiple forms on the same page, or dynamically generated schemas, that you may want to change it.

267.title: arrayProxy
267.content: A simple change: `fieldErrors` is renamed to `valueErrors`.

268.title: intProxy and numberProxy
268.content: The `emptyIfZero` setting is removed from `numberProxy` and `intProxy`.

269.title: The defaultValidators option has moved
269.content: Another simple change: If you've been using `defaultValidators`, set the value `'clear'` on the `validators` option instead.

270.title: Enums in schemas
270.content:
Previously, it was possible to post the name of the enum as a string, even if it was a numeric enum. That's not possible anymore:



For string enums, it works to post strings, of course.

271.title: Enums must have an explicit default value
271.content: Enums don't have a default "empty" value unlike other types, so it's not certain what the default value should be. Previously the first enum member was used, but v2 is a bit more strict. Therefore, you must specify a default value for enums explicitly:

272.title: Use isTainted to check tainted status
272.content:
A new `superForm.isTainted` method is available, to check whether any part of the form is tainted. Use it instead of checking the `$tainted` store, which may give unexpected results.



Speaking of tainted, it now keeps track of the original data, so if you go back to a previous value, it's not considered tainted anymore.

273.title: Schema/validation changes
273.content: The underlying data model for Superforms is now JSON Schema, which is what makes it possible to support all the validation libraries. Some changes had to be made for this to work:

274.title: No side-effects for default values.
274.content:
If no data is sent to `superValidate`, and no errors should be displayed, as is default in the load function:



Then the default values won't be parsed with the schema. In other words, no side-effects like `z.refine` will be executed. If you need initial validation of even the default data, set the `errors` option to `true`, and optionally clear the errors after validation:

275.title: Fields with default values aren't required anymore
275.content: In hindsight, this should have been the default, given the forgiving nature of the data coercion and parsing. When a default value exists, the field is not required anymore. If that field isn't posted, its default value will be added to `form.data`.

276.title: Components
276.content:
Generic components were previously using Zod types for type safety. It is simpler now:

TextInput.svelte



+page.svelte

277.title: superForm.fields is removed
277.content: The `fields` object returned from `superForm` was an inferior version of formFieldProxy, and has now been removed. Use `formFieldProxy` to create your own instead.

278.title: superForm does not support untainting specific fields anymore
278.content: You could previously choose what specific fields to untaint with a `fields` option, when updating `$form`. It was a rarely used feature that has now been removed.

279.title: onError "message" parameter is removed
279.content: Previously, there was a `message` parameter in the onError event. It's gone now, since it was pointing to the message store, and you might as well just assign it directly:

280.title: flashMessage.onError "message" parameter renamed to "flashMessage"
280.content: To be more consistent with the message parameter, the rarely used `flashMessage` option in `superForm` has an `onError` event with a `message` parameter, but it is now renamed to `flashMessage` to signify which message can actually be updated.

281.title: New features
281.content: Of course, there are also new features, so the migration will be worthwhile. Check the what's new page for more information.

283.title: Legacy version
283.content:
Superforms 1.x is available, so if you're still on version 0.x, please upgrade! No support can be given for the 0.x version.

[Migration guide 0.x -> 1.0](/migration)Migration guide 0.x -> 1.0[What's new in 1.0?](/whats-new-v1)What's new in 1.0?[0.x documentation](https://superforms-legacy.vercel.app/)0.x documentation

301.title: No side-effects for default values.
301.content:
If no data is sent to `superValidate`, and no errors should be displayed, as is default in the load function:



Then the default values won't be parsed with the schema. In other words, no side-effects like `z.refine` will be executed. If you need initial validation of even the default data, set the `errors` option to `true`, and optionally clear the errors after validation:

302.title: Fields with default values aren't required anymore
302.content: In hindsight, this should have been the default, given the forgiving nature of the data coercion and parsing. When a default value exists, the field is not required anymore. If that field isn't posted, its default value will be added to `form.data`.

303.title: Components
303.content:
Generic components were previously using Zod types for type safety. It is simpler now:

TextInput.svelte



+page.svelte

304.title: superForm.fields is removed
304.content: The `fields` object returned from `superForm` was an inferior version of formFieldProxy, and has now been removed. Use `formFieldProxy` to create your own instead.

305.title: superForm does not support untainting specific fields anymore
305.content: You could previously choose what specific fields to untaint with a `fields` option, when updating `$form`. It was a rarely used feature that has now been removed.

306.title: onError "message" parameter is removed
306.content: Previously, there was a `message` parameter in the onError event. It's gone now, since it was pointing to the message store, and you might as well just assign it directly:

307.title: flashMessage.onError "message" parameter renamed to "flashMessage"
307.content: To be more consistent with the message parameter, the rarely used `flashMessage` option in `superForm` has an `onError` event with a `message` parameter, but it is now renamed to `flashMessage` to signify which message can actually be updated.

308.title: New features
308.content: Of course, there are also new features, so the migration will be worthwhile. Check the what's new page for more information.

309.title: Superforms v2 - Migration guide
309.content:
/>

Version 2 is a big upgrade, because it now has the potential to support virtually every validation library out there. Of course, Zod is still perfectly usable with just a small modification to the code.

310.title: Changes
310.content: Here's a brief list of the changes, keep reading further down for details.

311.title: The biggest change (IMPORTANT)
311.content:
The biggest breaking change is that two options now follow the SvelteKit defaults more closely:

resetForm is now `true` as defaultresetForm is now `true` as defaulttaintedMessage is now `false` as defaulttaintedMessage is now `false` as default

But don't worry, there's no need to change these options on every form to migrate. Instead, add the following define in `vite.config.ts` to keep the original behavior:



You can do the same on a form-by-form basis by setting the `legacy` option on `superForm` to `true` as well.

312.title: superValidate
312.content:
Instead of a Zod schema, you now use an adapter for your favorite validation library. The following are currently supported:

LibraryAdapterRequires defaultsArktype`import { arktype } from 'sveltekit-superforms/adapters'`YesJoi`import { joi } from 'sveltekit-superforms/adapters'`NoTypeBox`import { typebox } from 'sveltekit-superforms/adapters'`NoValibot`import { valibot } from 'sveltekit-superforms/adapters'`NoYup`import { yup } from 'sveltekit-superforms/adapters'`NoZod`import { zod } from 'sveltekit-superforms/adapters'`NoWith the library installed and the adapter imported, all you need to do is wrap the schema with it:



The libraries in the list that requires defaults don't have full introspection capabilities (yet), in which case you need to supply the default values for the form data as an option:

313.title: Schema caching
313.content: In the example above, both the schema and the defaults are defined outside the load function, on the top level of the module. This is very important to make caching work. The adapter is memoized (cached) with its arguments, so they must be kept in memory. Therefore, define the schema, options and eventual default values for the adapter on the top level of a module, so they always refer to the same object.

314.title: Optimized client-side validation
314.content:
The client-side validation is using the smallest possible part of the adapter, to minimize the bundle size for the client. To use it, append `Client` to the adapter import, for example:



This works with the same schema as the one used on the server. If you need to switch schemas on the client (with `options.validators`), you need the full adapter.The built-in Superforms validator is now deprecated, since it requires you to do much of the type checking yourself. To keep using it, import `superformClient` and use the new `Infer` type to type it correctly with the schema, as in the following example. The input parameter can now be `undefined` as well, be sure to check for that case.



As said, this adapter requires you to do much of the error-prone type checking manually, so in general it is not a replacement for the other validation libraries. Use it only for a very good reason!

315.title: SuperValidated type parameters have changed
315.content:
If you have used type parameters for a call to `superValidate` before, or have been using the `SuperValidated` type, you now need to wrap the schema parameter with `Infer`:





If your schema uses transformations or pipes, so the input and output types are different, there's an `InferIn` type and a third type parameter that can be used.



Also, `constraints` are now optional in the `SuperValidated` type, since they won't be returned when posting data anymore, only when loading data, to save some bandwidth. This is only relevant if you're changing the constraints before calling `superForm`.

316.title: superValidateSync is renamed to defaults
316.content:
The quite popular `superValidateSync` function has changed, since it's not possible to make a synchronous validation anymore (not all validation libaries are synchronous). So if you've validated data with `superValidateSync` (in its first parameter), be aware that superValidateSync cannot do validation anymore. You need to use a `+page.ts` to do proper validation, as described on the SPA page.

Since this is a bit of a security issue, `superValidateSync` has been renamed to `defaults`.

Fortunately though, a quick Github search reveals that most of its usages are with the schema only, which requires no validation and no `+page.ts`. In that case, just call `defaults` with your adapter and eventual initial data, and you're good to go:





Note that `superValidate` can be used anywhere but on the top-level of Svelte components, so it's not completely removed from the client and SPA usage. But client-side validation is more of a convenience than ensuring data integrity. Always let an external API or a server request do a proper validation of the data before it's stored or used somewhere.

317.title: validate method with no arguments is renamed to validateForm
317.content: Previously, you could do `const result = await validate()` to get a validation result for the whole form. This overload caused a lot of typing issues, so it has now been split into `validate` for fields, and `validateForm` for the whole form. Just replace the calls to `validate()` with `validateForm()` to fix this.

318.title: id option must be a string
318.content: It's not possible to set the `id` option to `undefined` anymore, which is very rare anyway. By default, the id is automatically set to a string hash of the schema. It's only for multiple forms on the same page, or dynamically generated schemas, that you may want to change it.

319.title: arrayProxy
319.content: A simple change: `fieldErrors` is renamed to `valueErrors`.

320.title: intProxy and numberProxy
320.content: The `emptyIfZero` setting is removed from `numberProxy` and `intProxy`.

321.title: The defaultValidators option has moved
321.content: Another simple change: If you've been using `defaultValidators`, set the value `'clear'` on the `validators` option instead.

322.title: Enums in schemas
322.content:
Previously, it was possible to post the name of the enum as a string, even if it was a numeric enum. That's not possible anymore:



For string enums, it works to post strings, of course.

323.title: Enums must have an explicit default value
323.content: Enums don't have a default "empty" value unlike other types, so it's not certain what the default value should be. Previously the first enum member was used, but v2 is a bit more strict. Therefore, you must specify a default value for enums explicitly:

324.title: Use isTainted to check tainted status
324.content:
A new `superForm.isTainted` method is available, to check whether any part of the form is tainted. Use it instead of checking the `$tainted` store, which may give unexpected results.



Speaking of tainted, it now keeps track of the original data, so if you go back to a previous value, it's not considered tainted anymore.

325.title: Schema/validation changes
325.content: The underlying data model for Superforms is now JSON Schema, which is what makes it possible to support all the validation libraries. Some changes had to be made for this to work:

326.title: No side-effects for default values.
326.content:
If no data is sent to `superValidate`, and no errors should be displayed, as is default in the load function:



Then the default values won't be parsed with the schema. In other words, no side-effects like `z.refine` will be executed. If you need initial validation of even the default data, set the `errors` option to `true`, and optionally clear the errors after validation:

327.title: Fields with default values aren't required anymore
327.content: In hindsight, this should have been the default, given the forgiving nature of the data coercion and parsing. When a default value exists, the field is not required anymore. If that field isn't posted, its default value will be added to `form.data`.

328.title: Components
328.content:
Generic components were previously using Zod types for type safety. It is simpler now:

TextInput.svelte



+page.svelte

329.title: superForm.fields is removed
329.content: The `fields` object returned from `superForm` was an inferior version of formFieldProxy, and has now been removed. Use `formFieldProxy` to create your own instead.

330.title: superForm does not support untainting specific fields anymore
330.content: You could previously choose what specific fields to untaint with a `fields` option, when updating `$form`. It was a rarely used feature that has now been removed.

331.title: onError "message" parameter is removed
331.content: Previously, there was a `message` parameter in the onError event. It's gone now, since it was pointing to the message store, and you might as well just assign it directly:

332.title: flashMessage.onError "message" parameter renamed to "flashMessage"
332.content: To be more consistent with the message parameter, the rarely used `flashMessage` option in `superForm` has an `onError` event with a `message` parameter, but it is now renamed to `flashMessage` to signify which message can actually be updated.

333.title: New features
333.content: Of course, there are also new features, so the migration will be worthwhile. Check the what's new page for more information.

/>

If you have gone through the Concepts section of this site, maybe you want to test out some things. The easiest way to do that is to use the Stackblitz repos prepared for each validation library:

[Valibot](https://stackblitz.com/edit/superforms-2-testing-valibot?file=src%2Froutes%2F%2Bpage.server.ts,src%2Froutes%2F%2Bpage.svelte)Valibot[Zod](https://stackblitz.com/edit/superforms-2-testing?file=src%2Froutes%2F%2Bpage.server.ts,src%2Froutes%2F%2Bpage.svelte)Zod

340.title: Rate limiting
340.content:
/>

Superforms has a basic client-side prevention of multiple form submissions. But you may want to limit the rate of form submissions on the server as well, to prevent misuse and spamming. 

A useful library for this is sveltekit-rate-limiter, which makes it easy to rate limit password resets, account registration, etc. It not only works with forms but all requests, so API limiting is another use for it.

Installation and usage instructions are available at its Github repo:https://github.com/ciscoheat/sveltekit-rate-limiter

353.title: SuperDebug
353.content:
`SuperDebug` is a debugging component that gives you colorized and nicely formatted output for any data structure, usually `$form` returned from `superForm`. It also shows the current page status in the top right corner.

It's not limited to the Superforms data, other use cases includes debugging plain objects, promises, stores and more.

354.title: Props reference
354.content: PropTypeDefault valueDescriptiondataanyData to be displayed by SuperDebug. The only required prop.displayboolean`true`Whether to show or hide SuperDebug.statusboolean`true`Whether to show or hide the HTTP status code of the current page.labelstring`""`Add a label to SuperDebug, useful when using multiple instances on a page.collapsibleboolean`false`Makes the component collapsible on a per-route basis.collapsedboolean`false`If the component is `collapsible`, sets it to initially collapsed.stringTruncatenumber`120`Truncate long string field valuns of the data prop. Set to `0` to disable truncating.rawboolean`false`Skip promise and store detection when `true`.functionsboolean`false`Enables the display of fields of the data prop that are functions.theme"default", "vscode"`"default"`Display theme, which can also be customized with CSS variables.refHTMLPreElementReference to the pre element that contains the data.
354.code:
<SuperDebug
  data={any}
  display={true}
  status={true}
  label=''
  collapsible={false}
  collapsed={false}
  stringTruncate={120}
  raw={false}
  functions={false}
  theme='default'
  ref={HTMLPreElement} 
/>

356.title: With a label
356.content: A label is useful when using multiple instance of SuperDebug.

357.title: Promise support
357.content: To see this in action, scroll to the product data below and hit refresh.

358.title: Composing debug data
358.content:
If you want to debug multiple stores/objects in the same instance.



<SuperDebug data={{$form, $errors}} />

359.title: Displaying files
359.content: SuperDebug displays `File` and `FileList` objects as well:

360.title: SuperDebug loves stores
360.content: You can pass a store directly to SuperDebug:

362.title: CSS variables available for customization
362.content: Note that styling the component produces the side-effect described in the Svelte docs.

363.title: Page data
363.content: Debugging Svelte's `$page` data, when the going gets tough. Since it can contain a lot of data, using the `collapsible` prop is convenient.
363.code:
<script lang="ts">
  import { page } from '$app/stores';
</script>

<SuperDebug label="$page data" data={$page} collapsible />

389.title: Help & Support
389.content: There are two ways of getting support with using Superforms:

390.title: Free support
390.content: If you're using Superforms in a personal or non-profit project, support is completely free; a star on Github is more than enough if you want to show your appreciation. Join #free-support on Discord and ask away!

391.title: Commercial support
391.content:
If you're making or aiming to make money on your project, a donation proportional to the current profit of the project or the company you work for, will give you a month of commercial support. Donate with one of the options below, then ask in the #commercial-support channel on Discord, or on Github.

For a longer period, you can make a monthly donation. Any $10 or higher monthly donation will be listed on the Sponsors page with a picture and link, and on Discord as a Sponsor. Many thanks if you want to support Open Source Software in this way!

392.title: Bug reporting
392.content:
Please report bugs as an issue on Github.

Fixing bugs and working on new features will be handled in due time, but if you want to speed up the process, a donation is welcome, or you can submit a pull request, since with open source, we can also pay with our time.
